name: Decay Series Analysis
what: This subtopic covers how to read and interpret decay series diagrams that show the sequence of radioactive decays a heavy nucleus undergoes until it reaches a stable isotope.
why: Understanding decay series explains why mining uranium produces multiple radioactive substances and how heavy elements naturally transform into stable lead isotopes over geological time.

items.title: I can explain what a radioactive decay series represents
items.what: A decay series is the sequence of radioactive decays a heavy unstable nucleus undergoes until it reaches a stable isotope. Each decay produces a daughter nucleus that may itself be radioactive.
items.why: Decay series explain why uranium ore contains many different radioactive elements and why the heat from these decays keeps Earth's core molten.
items.example: Uranium-238 decays through 14 steps, producing thorium, protactinium, radium, radon, polonium, and bismuth isotopes before finally becoming stable lead-206.

items.title: I can identify alpha decay on a decay series diagram
items.what: On decay diagrams, alpha decay appears as a diagonal arrow pointing left and down. The mass number decreases by 4 (moving down) and the atomic number decreases by 2 (moving left).
items.why: Recognising decay types on diagrams allows us to predict what daughter nucleus forms and write the corresponding decay equation.

items.title: I can identify beta decay on a decay series diagram
items.what: On decay diagrams, beta-minus decay appears as a horizontal arrow pointing right. The mass number stays the same while the atomic number increases by 1.
items.why: Beta decay moves nuclei toward the belt of stability by changing the neutron-to-proton ratio without changing the total number of nucleons.
items.example: On the uranium-238 decay diagram, the arrow from Th-234 to Pa-234 goes horizontally right, indicating beta decay: ¬≤¬≥‚Å¥‚Çâ‚ÇÄTh ‚Üí ¬≤¬≥‚Å¥‚Çâ‚ÇÅPa + ‚Å∞‚Çã‚ÇÅe.

items.title: I can determine the stable end product of a decay series
items.what: Each natural decay series ends with a specific stable isotope of lead. The uranium-238 series ends at lead-206, the uranium-235 series ends at lead-207, and the thorium-232 series ends at lead-208.
items.why: Knowing the end product allows geologists to date rocks by measuring the ratio of parent to daughter isotopes and explains why lead is relatively abundant on Earth.
items.example: The uranium-238 decay series passes through 14 radioactive isotopes before terminating at stable lead-206, which has 82 protons and 124 neutrons.

items.title: I can extract half-life information from decay series diagrams
items.what: Decay series diagrams typically show the half-life for each decay step. These range from microseconds (polonium-214: 160 Œºs) to billions of years (uranium-238: 4.5 √ó 10‚Åπ years).
items.why: Half-life information explains which daughter products accumulate in a sample and which decay almost immediately after being formed.
items.example: In the uranium-238 series, radium-226 has a half-life of 1600 years, long enough to accumulate in uranium ore, while polonium-214 (160 Œºs) decays almost instantly.
